items.title: New York City Unveils Parking App Pilot Program
items.abstract: Parking on New York City streets can be frustrating, but the city Transportation Department will try to alleviate the problem using a smartphone app.

items.title: Competition Designed to Spread Basic Technologies
items.abstract: The World Bank is organizing a competition to find solutions that address access to technology in developing countries.

items.title: How Big Is That Park? City Now Has the Answer
items.abstract: Over the last three years, the city has been resurveying its parks, relying on satellites instead of 19th century cartographers. There were both winners and losers.

items.title: Many Pleas for Quiet, but City Still Thunders
items.abstract: Despite numerous noise codes and aggressive campaigns to silence New York City over the last century, the racket has roared on.

items.title: Student Crossword | Geography of the Middle East
items.abstract: Learn more about the geography of the Middle East by playing our crossword, either online or in print.

items.title: Cities to Untangle Traffic Snarls, With Help From Alphabet Unit
items.abstract: A federal Transportation Department partnership with the Alphabet unit Sidewalk Labs will put the power of Google’s data into a traffic management system.

items.title: In Mexico City, Exploring a Volcano Sacred to the Aztecs
items.abstract: The Hill of the Star, once one of the most important Aztec religious sites, has been lost to time. But a visit there can still be transportive.

items.title: Chris Christie Approves Financial Rescue Plan for Atlantic City
items.abstract: The struggling seaside resort in New Jersey must meet several measures to avoid bankruptcy, or the state will take over, according to the legislation.

items.title: No Driver? Bring It On. How Pittsburgh Became Uber’s Testing Ground
items.abstract: Uber’s experiment with autonomous vehicles is proceeding with the blessing of city officials, who have pretty much just stayed out of the way.

items.title: In ‘By the People,’ Designing for the Underserved and Overlooked
items.abstract: In this exhibition at the Cooper Hewitt, everyday citizens cook up solutions to what ails their own communities.
keywords: By the People: Designing a Better America (Exhibit)

items.title: Urban-Farming Camps Have Kids Asking, Where’s the Healthy Food?
items.abstract: At summer programs in Harlem and the Bronx, children grow crops and talk about the limited sources of good nutrition in their neighborhoods.

items.title: One Cure for Pandemic Doldrums: Walking Every Street in Your City
items.abstract: In Peoria, Ill., and elsewhere, pedestrians said their quests brought a sense of purpose and helped them appreciate long-overlooked hometown sights.

items.title: G.O.P. Gains Strength on N.Y. City Council, as a Democrat Breaks Ranks
items.abstract: Progressive Democrats and conservative Republicans are clashing on what may be the most ideologically diverse City Council ever.
